text: Hello!
My name is Ann from howtocookthat.

Today we are going to be talking about using
sugar paste or fondant for decorating kids'

or any birthday cakes, or cakes that you want
to make.

This is what fondant or sugar paste looks
like, it comes in a nice, thick plastic sealed
packet; you can also make it.

One of the main advantages of working with
your sugar paste or fondant is that you can
make it ahead.

So, you can make little figurines or whatever
you need, the detailed pieces to put on your
cake, up to a couple of months ahead.
Let it dry, out and go hard.

Then on the day before the birthday make a
cake, decorate it with buttercream, or flat

layer of fondant, anything you are wanting;
and then just put your details on.
So, it makes it heaps easier to do.

Just a few things you might want to get together
before you start so we'll go through those
first.

The first thing that I like to use use is
some of the baking paper, and just put it
down on the bench.

What that does is it just stops the sugar
paste or the fondant from sticking to your
bench top.

So you don't want to make a nice work of art
or some lettering and then not be able to
get it off the bench without it breaking.
It also makes it easier to move around.
And the other things you might need:
A pizza cutter.

The reason why a pizza cutter is when you're
cutting with it through that fondant, if you've

rolled it out, a knife tends to drag and change
the shape of the fondant, whereas the pizza
cutter does a nice straight line with that.

A fondant rolling pin is a really great tool;
they're just nice and smooth, nice and simple
and easy to use.

They come in all different sizes, but for
the sake of making small decorations, a smaller
one is fine.

I also like to have a straw, various different
sizes of straws.
A skewer.

You can buy specific tools for doing decorating
but you don't really need them you can probably

find it no matter what you're making, you
have around the house what you need.
And then a knife as well is also useful.
And some icing sugar.

The reason why the icing sugar is if it's
too sticky or if it's starting to stick to
stuff, you just put some icing sugar on there.

You are also going to need a small bowl of
water; it's just when we're sticking pieces
together.

Now currently we have whole lump of white
fondant here.

When you get it out it might be a bit hard,
you just need to give it a bit of a knead
to get it soft and workable and pliable.
It should be about the consistency of playdoh.
That's what you want.

With sugar paste and fondant, you then need
to color it.

We've got colorings here, in my handy little
box.

If you're wanting something which has a lot
of black in it, then I suggest that you pre-purchase

black fondant or black sugar paste, I've got
a chunk of that here.

Only because otherwise you'll use an awful
lot of color to give it that true black.

It's easier just to buy a roll of the black,
and keep in the freezer for whenever you're
doing decorating and you need black.

Just make sure you've triple-wrapped it in
thick plastic, put it in the freezer and you'll
be fine.
Yu can get different types of coloring.

This is a typical food coloring you'll see
in the shops.

It's very watered down and not ideal for sugar
paste, because by the time you add enough

to get those intense colors, you are going
to have already made your sugar paste or fondant
too sticky to work with.

What you want is your gel colors, which look
more like this, they're like a jelly.

What we want to do is just grab a knife, dip
it into the gel color of the color of your
choice.

We don't want too much, and I do want quite
a bright yellow, so I've got a fair bit on
my knife.

And then just stab it in to the fondant, like
that, wipe it all off your knife, so that
you're not wasting any.

Okay, once you get it all off, then what you
want to do -- you don't want this on your

fingers, you want it all on the sugar paste
-- so fold it in half so that it's in the
middle.
Fold any bits you can see into the middle.

You will get some on your fingers, it's inevitable,
but this way makes it a little bit less.
Okay?
Keep folding it into the middle.

Once you're starting to get a bit of that
color through, you want it to be nice and
smooth.

So see how at the moment it has areas of white,
areas of yellow; the best way to make it nice

and smooth is to put it on the palm of your
hand, and with the other palm, squash it.

And just continue doing that until you get
a nice and smooth color.

I can tell already that this is not the bright
yellow of the Pokemon that I'm making, so
I need to add more.

Okay, once you've done one color, if you have
another color to mix, make sure you wash your
hands and dry them really well.

The reason why you wash your hands obviously
is because if you have some yellow or some

residual of the color you've just done, you
don't want to mix that in.
